io.atomix.group

Class GroupElection

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.atomix.group.GroupElection

  • public class GroupElection
extends Object
    Manages an election among DistributedGroup members.

    Within each group, a leader is elected automatically by the group's replicated state machine. Group elections are fair, meaning the first member to join the group will always be elected the leader for the first term. Elections provide a unique, monotonically increasing token called a term which can be used to resolve leader conflicts across group members. At most one leader is guaranteed to exist for any term, and the leader for a given term is guaranteed to be the same for all members of the group.

    The group-wide election can be accessed on the DistributedGroup object via DistributedGroup.election(). Because they're low overhead - action only needs to be taken when a member joins or leaves the group - group members always participate in an election.

    To listen for a group member to be elected leader, register a election listener. 

       
   DistributedGroup group = atomix.getGroup("election-group").get();

   group.onElection(term -> {
     term.leader().connection().send("hi!");
   });
    The election listener callback will be called with the GroupMember that was elected leader once complete. Similarly, you can access the current leader via the GroupTerm.leader() getter. The current leader is guaranteed to be the leader for the current term(). However, the leader may be null if no leader has been elected for the current term.
    Author:

        public GroupTerm term()

      • onElection

        public Listener<GroupTerm> onElection(Consumer<GroupTerm> callback)
        Registers a callback to be called when a member of the group is elected leader.

        The provided callback will be called when notification of a leader change is received by the resource. The leader will be assigned only after the term() has been incremented. When the callback is called, the leader is guaranteed to be associated with the current term, and no other leader will ever be associated with the same term (assuming the cluster is persistent).

        The returned Listener can be used to unregister the term listener via Listener.close(). 

           
   Listener<GroupMember> listener = group.election().onElection(leader -> {
     ...
   });

   // Unregister the listener
   listener.close();
        Parameters:
        callback - The callback to call when a member of the group is elected leader.
        Returns:
        The leader election listener.

        public String toString()
